_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Denaturant tank vents, welds, and level guages

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Badger State Ethanol, LLC



Badger State Ethanol, LLC (BSE) is a fully operational ethanol production facility which began operations in October 2002.  BSE is designed to produce fuel-grade ethanol. Wet and dried distillers grains (WDGS/ DDGS) are byproducts of ethanol production and are sold to local markets as animal feed. Ethanol production activities fall under the SIC code 2869, Industrial Chemicals, Not Elsewhere Classified.



Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies



BSE is committed to worker and public safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by BSE's investment in accident prevention, through the establishment of a facility that is well designed, installed, operated and maintained. In addition, training is considered a crucial part of safe operation and accident presentation. Staff is trained about spill prevention and control methods as well as emergency response plans in place at the facility.

It is BSE policy to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances and if a release does occur, plant personnel will respond to contain the release as necessary. BSE management is dedicated to safety, spill prevention and proper emergency response.



Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances



The BSE Ethanol Plant is located at 820 West 17th Street in southeast Monroe, Wisconsin. The site is located in the northeast corner of Section 4, Township 1 North, Range 7 East, Green County, Wisconsin. The site consists of approximately 95 acres and is bounded by Wisconsin & Southern Railroad Company to the south and by West 17th Street to the north.

The facility operates 24 hours per day, 7 days per week for the purpose of manufacturing fuel grade ethanol from corn.  The substances which BSE has onsite that are regulated by the RMP program are Anhydrous Ammonia and Denaturant (natural gasoline) which is considered a flammable mixture.  The anhydrous ammonia

is used as a chemical processing aid and is consumed in the manufacturing process. It is stored in a single anhydrous ammonia tank. The denaturant (natural gasoline) is used to denature the ethanol so that it is unfit for human consumption before being shipped offsite. Denaturant is generally stored onsite in the denaturant and final product storage tanks.



Five Year Accident History



BSE has been subject to RMP criteria since it began storing anhydrous ammonia and denaturant (natural gasoline) onsite.

In the last five years, BSE has had no RMP reportable incidents.



Emergency Response Program Information



BSE is included in the Community Emergency Response Plan and therefore does not have its own Emergency Response Plan for emergencies requiring a high level of emergency support. In the case that an incident occurred which required high level emergency response, BSE would call 911 for the necessary fire, medical or other emergency support. 

As explained above, BSE is committed to worker and public safety and has invested in training and equipment to prevent chemical spills and other emergency situations. In the event of a chemical spill, plant personnel will respond to contain the release, as necessary. Some physical aspects of the plant would also help the personnel contain a potential spill. For example, all tanks that contain denaturant are located in a large, bermed containment area that is separated from the plant.  A release from one of these tanks would be prevented from migrating off-site, and a fire could be extinguished before it spreads to other units at the facility.  In addition, a manual shut off valve in the ammonia tank would help limit the volume of an ammonia spill. 



General Accidental Release Prevention Program



BSE is subject to RMP Prevention Program Level 3.  BSE is fulfilling its duties to comply with the EPA requirements of 40 CFR Part 68.115(d) through the completion of this RMP and similar efforts regulated by OSHA's Proces

s Safety Management standard (29 CFR 1910.119).  BSE has complied with Process safety information, safe work practices such as Hot Work, Confined Space Entry and Lockout/Tagout, and operations and maintenance procedures are documented on-site. Periodic functions such as process hazard analyses (PHA), training, management of change, pre-startup safety reviews, and incident investigation are conducted on a regular basis.  

The denaturant tank is equipped with tank level sensors and alarms and has a bermed containment structure that surrounds the entire tank farm.  The anhydrous ammonia tank is equipped with a manual shut off valve.  However, BSE began to use urea as the base for the ethanol fermentation process in April of 2012.  BSE installed a blind to temporarily disable the ammonia flow into the fermentation tank until use is advantageous.  However, ammonia is still able to flow into the slurry tank.



These chemical specific prevention measures minimize the risk for an RMP reportable incident.  Compliance audits of the RMP Prevention Program will be conducted on a regular basis to assure compliance with EPA and OSHA regulations.   





Planned Changes to Improve Safety



As previously mentioned, BSE is committed to protecting its employees, the greater community and the environment from the release of hazardous substances used in the ethanol fuel production process. BSE management is committed to promoting a safe work environment and will continue to provide its employees with the necessary training, tools, and ongoing support to operate the ethanol production facility in a safe and efficient manner. Periodic audits will help us assure that we are doing everything reasonable to minimize the risk and mitigate the effects of an accidental release.
